body.p: College Students and Drinking Habits: A public health official is studying differences in drinking habits among students at two different universities. They collect a random sample of students independently from each of the two universities and ask each student how many alcoholic drinks they consumed in the previous week.

The official conducts a two-sample t-test to determine whether these data provide significant evidence that students at University 1 drink more than students at University 2. The test statistic is t = 2.64 with a p-value 0.005.
Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion?

input.choice: The samples provide significant evidence that students at University 1 drink more than students at University 2.
The samples do not provide statistically significant evidence that there is a difference in drinking habits at the two universities.
We cannot use the t-test in this case because the variables (number of drinks) are likely skewed to the right at each university.

response.feedback: Correct. A p-value this small indicates statistically significant results.
Incorrect. A p-value this small indicates statistically significant results.
Incorrect. Although the two variables are likely skewed to the right, we can proceed with a two-sample t-test because we have large enough samples.

The samples do not provide statistically significant evidence that there is a difference in starting salaries of chemical engineering and electrical engineering graduates at the University of Texas at Austin for 2013–2014.
We cannot use the t-test in this case because the variables (starting salary of engineering graduates) may not be normally distributed.
